http://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/05/arts/05iht-lon05.html "A Shrew, and Broadway, Tamed" "LONDON -- Samantha Spiro has terrifically expressive eyebrows, which is no mean attribute to possess when playing Katherina, otherwise known as Kate, in ''The Taming of the Shrew.'' This is the famously vexed Shakespeare comedy that can leave playgoers raising those same brows, perturbed by the sexual politics of a piece suggesting from its very title that women are there to be domesticated. Just how uncool is that? And yet, one look at Ms. Spiro and we know that she means business, as does the wonderful Simon Paisley Day playing the sparring partner-turned-husband, Petruchio, who in this ''cursed'' heroine recognizes from the start that he has met his match."

The children listened wide-eyed as she spoke (''This royal throne of kings, this scepter'd isle ...''), then beamed as she handed over a small card showing Shakespeare's head superimposed over a jeans-and-sneakers-wearing body. http://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/27/arts/27iht-design27.html "Venice Rediscovers Its Glass Treasures" "VENICE -- When fire blazed through the Venini glassworks at Murano in the Venetian Lagoon in 1972, it destroyed most of the buildings and their contents. Among the losses was the archive of drawings, documents and photographs that charted the development of Venini's glassware in the five decades since the company was founded. Priceless and irreplaceable, the archive perished in the blaze, or so it was thought. A year ago, the archive was found, entirely by chance, in part of the glassworks where it had lain unseen for years. Venini charged the historian and curator Marino Barovier with putting it in order, and the material he unearthed, including sketches amplified by designers' notes and complete sets of furnace drawings from the 1930s and 1940s, have shed new light on the design and production of some of the finest glassware of the 20th century."

http://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/26/arts/aug-26-sept-1.html "Aug. 26 -- Sept. 1" "THE novelist Ian Fleming was not pleased when he learned that his greatest creation, James Bond, was played by Sean Connery in ''Dr. No,'' the first in the film series. http://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/25/arts/25iht-conway25.html "Reclaiming a Fading Welsh Poet" "TRAWSFYNYDD, NORTH WALES -- To win the chair at the annual National Eisteddfod cultural festival is the highest honor to which any Welsh poet can aspire. http://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/18/arts/18iht-loomis18.html "Three Operas by Rossini Make Italian Festival Well Worth the Trip" "PESARO, ITALY -- Last month the Caramoor International Music Festival in Katonah, New York, presented Rossini's ''Ciro in Babilonia'' in a bel canto opera series that under the conductor Will Crutchfield's informed leadership has gratified New York audiences since the 1990s. http://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/15/arts/15iht-loomis15.html "At Innsbruck Festival, Opera as It Is Rarely Seen Today" "INNSBRUCK, AUSTRIA -- Back in the 20th century when people began wondering whether operas prior to Gluck and Mozart were worth performing, they discovered works of essentially two types. One followed a fast-paced, anything-goes approach that mixed serious and comic scenes, included bawdy humor and didn't worry about niceties of plot. The mixture of serious and comic elements gave these operas, which were cultivated primarily in 17th-century Venice, a kind of Shakespearean dimension.The second type attempted to make opera more respectable. Comic scenes were banned. Librettos took a loftier tone. The pace slowed down with longer arias and fewer of them. As with French Classical drama, fixed rules governed issues like the entrances and exits of characters. These operas originated in 18th-century Naples and spread widely. Handel's operas are essentially of this type, but as Italian operas written by a German for an English audience, they are sui generis. (French opera, by the way, was always a thing unto itself.)"

http://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/05/arts/05weekahead.html "Aug. 5 -- 11" "DETAILS have been scant about ''Heartless,'' the new play by SAM SHEPARD that begins an Off Broadway run this week, but for Shepard fans it hardly matters. http://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/25/arts/25iht-loomis25.html "Rossini and Contemporaries, Snuggly at Home in the Black Forest" "BAD WILDBAD, GERMANY -- In 1856 Gioachino Rossini, never known for robust health, spent several weeks in this spa town in the Black Forest and apparently found it enjoyable and productive. Having written his last opera in 1829, the 64-year-old composer was sufficiently rejuvenated to compose again -- not opera, but the pieces he dubbed ''Sins of Old Age'' (''Péchés de Vieillesse''). The town never forgot his visit and in 1989 established a festival known as Rossini in Wildbad. The festival, which ended its 2012 festival on July 22, differs from its illustrious cousin, the Rossini Festival in the composer's birthplace of Pesaro, Italy, by allowing operas by Rossini's contemporaries to share the limelight. A few years ago it presented Meyerbeer's ''Semiramide'' -- a title well-known to Rossini fans -- and this year the nod went to the Neapolitan composer Saverio Mercadante and the one opera, ''I Briganti,'' that he composed for Théâtre-Italien in Paris."

http://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/22/arts/july-22-28.html "July 22 -- 28" "BUSTS by the German Baroque sculptor FRANZ XAVER MESSERSCHMIDT of men weeping or grimacing, yawning or looking as though they are about to scream have fascinated artists, collectors, scholars and museum curators for more than two centuries. Recent shows devoted to his work have been on view at the Louvre in Paris and the Neue Galerie in New York. Now the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles is taking a new look at Messerschmidt. Its show -- ''Messerschmidt and Modernity'' -- which opens at the Getty Center on Tuesday, will present these mid-18th-century sculptures. But rather than explore Messerschmidt's work by itself, the exhibition will include modern and contemporary works that underscore his enduring influence. During the last 13 years of his life -- between 1770 and 1783 -- he produced a group of 69 so-called character heads, which he intended as a way of representing the spectrum of human emotion and which he either carved in alabaster or cast in a lead or tin alloy. Eight of them will be on view at the Getty, including the museum's ''Vexed Man.'' To illustrate Messerschmidt's influence, the show will also feature work by Tony Cragg, Bruce Nauman, Pierre Picot and Cindy Sherman. (310) 440-7300, getty.edu."

http://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/28/arts/28iht-design28.html "How Italian Designers Left Their Imprint on Global Graphic Design" "MILAN -- Every so often a design project emerges that design purists love, but lots of other people hate, including many of those who were intended to use it. A prime example is the 1972 New York subway map, a masterpiece of visual ingenuity, which depicted the labyrinthine network as an orderly series of straight lines, all running at 45- or 90-degree angles from the stations. The hitch was that the map's designer had to ignore geographic reality in order to ''tidy up'' the tangled system. Some New Yorkers were outraged by the result, and voiced their concerns loudly. http://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/27/arts/may-27-june-2.html "May 27 -- June 2" "THE Accademia Carrara in Bergamo holds one of Italy's most distinguished collections of Venetian painting. And while it is closed for restoration, some of its choicest items are on the road. The itinerary brings 15 pictures to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in ''BELLINI, TITIAN AND LOTTO: NORTH ITALIAN PAINTINGS FROM THE ACCADEMIA CARRARA, BERGAMO.'' There are, of course, things by the superstars of the title. Giovanni Bellini's ''Pietà with the Virgin and Saint John,'' dated between 1455 and 1460, is a mournful complement to his later ''Madonna and Child,'' which is in the Met's collection. The single Titian is the very early ''Orpheus and Eurydice,'' thought to have been done between 1508 and 1512. And from Lorenzo Lotto we have a charming portrait of Lucina Brembati, who wears a large jeweled toothpick on a gold chain around her neck. Less familiar sights are three smallish narrative paintings from a Lotto altarpiece that has not traveled. And then there are artists you probably won't know at all, like Giovanni Cariani, Andrea Previtali, Moretto da Brescia and Vincenzo Foppa. But really, they're just old friends that you have yet to meet. Through Sept. 3; Metropolitan Museum of Art; (212) 535-7710, metmuseum.org."

http://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/26/arts/26iht-melikian26.html "The Islamic Tide and Byzantium" "NEW YORK -- The fascinating art show ''Byzantium and Islam,'' subtitled ''Age of Transition, 7th-9th Century,'' on view at the Metropolitan Museum through July 8, is one of those rare exhibitions that make one marvel about the unpredictable twists of history. Regardless of their respective identities in the more distant past, by the seventh century these lands shared a common language, Aramaic."

http://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/24/arts/24iht-cannes24.html "Émilie Dequenne's Latest Unraveling" "CANNES -- Émilie Dequenne was not yet 18 when she played the title role in Jean-Pierre and Luc Dardenne's ''Rosetta'' in 1999.
